fields.Title of Presentation: Forward modeling of ground penetrating radar (GPR) and electric  resistivity tomography (ERT) using finite difference time domain and  finite volume methods, first steps for a joint inversion.
fields.Description/Abstract:
By introducing an electromagnetic field into the ground with either a steady

electric current or a time varying electromagnetic wave (ERT, GPR respec-
tively), we can image the shallow subsurface by measuring the field response

near the air-ground interface and then inverting for subsurface properties using

our forward models.

Both these methods are sensitive to electrical conductivity, although the elec-
tric field response generated by GPR is most sensitive to high frequency con-
ductivity, while the response given by ERT is most sensitive to low frequency

conductivity.

Accurate computational tools for modeling these electromagnetic fields in our

physical region of interest can then be used for a joint inversion by regularizing

both (conductivity complimentary) data sets.

We develop two dimensional forward models for GPR and ERT in theory and

computationally using finite difference time domain and finite volume method

respectively, together with numerical results from synthetically produced data.

We also develop novel theoretical approaches for a joint inversion using GPR

and ERT data.
